“Good-bye, Rodya,” Pulcheria Alexandrovna said, embarrassed.  
“Good-bye, Nastasya. Ah, I’ve said good-bye again.”  
She fluttered out, forgetting to greet Sonia.  
Avdotya Romanovna bowed to Sonia.  
Sonia curtsied, confusion etched on her face.  
“Dounia, good-bye,” Raskolnikov called from the passage.  
“Give me your hand.”  
“I did give it to you. Have you forgotten?”  
“Never mind, give it to me again.”  
He squeezed her fingers warmly.  
Dounia smiled, flushed, and left happy.  
“Come, that’s capital,” he said to Sonia, brightening.  
“God give peace to the dead. The living have still to live.”  
Sonia stared, surprised by his sudden brightness.  
Memories of his dead father swirled in his mind.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The characters experience a mix of embarrassment and emotional connection as they say their goodbyes, highlighting their complex relationships.
